Nomination And Election
OfUpperclass Officers To
Be Held Next Two Weeks
Election of the upper class officers
for the current year, to be held this
week and next, was to begin yesterday when nominations for sophomore class officers were received in
Latrobe Hall.
Sophomore class elections will be
held this Thursday when nominations
for the junior class officers will also
take place.
Next Monday the junior elections
and senior nominations will be held,
while senior officers will be elected
on the following Thursday.
Polls will be open on election days
from 12.30 to 1.30 p. m. A student
must have paid his class dues in order to be eligible to vote.

John Yellott, who was graduated
from the School of Engineering in
1931, and who received his master's
degree in mechanical engineering two
years later, has becothe an instructor
3.
at the Stevens Institute of Technolf
ogy, it was learned Saturday. He
served during 1933-34 on the University of Rochester faculty.
In order to win his M. E. degree
from the Hopkins, Yellott wrote his
thesis on an invention of his own by
Which steam flow in nozzles could be
examined optically.
Prominent in undergraduate affairs, he was chairman of the 1931
June Week which featured Lombardo's Royal Canadians, member of the
Student Council for two years, president of the Interfraternity Board,
- track "letter" man, and member of
the "Y" Board of Managers. He is
a member of Tau Beta Pi national
honorary engineering fraternity, Sigma Xi scientific fraternity, and Omicron Delta Kappa honorary activities fraternity.

Engineering School
Truthfully one of if not the most
versatile of the Hopkins football
players is Reuben Pasarew. Born in
this city August 12, 1914, Rube, as
he is known on the campus, attended primary school in this city before entering the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.
While at Poly Pasarew starred in
three sports: football, basketball and
lacrosse. In his senior year at Poly
Rube was captain of the lacrosse
team and received mention in the
All-Maryland selections.
Versatile Player
In the fall of 1932 he matriculated
in the School of Engineering at the
Johns Hopkins and promptly proceeded to "throw his hat into the
football ring." Pasarew made he
varsity in his first year at school,
playing most of the time on the line.
Last year, due to injuries to several
of the players and scarcity of varsity
material, Coach Van Orman alternated Rube in the backfield. But this
season finds Pasarew holding down
an end post for the Blue Jay eleven.

of Captain Bill McClean. His excellent passing, kicking and field generalship led the Black and Blue thru

thrust was broken up by their hard
charging and tackling.

showed a definite ability to pass their
way into scoring territory.

Our shortcoming lies in the rushing attack. Several off-tackle runs
were well executed but a majority of
the line bucks lacked everything that
should go with 'em.
Another very evident weakness was
the lack of reserve strength. On
several important occasions last Saturday, it was clear that the coaching
staff was at a loss when substitutes
were necessary. There doesn't seem
as though anything can be done
about this unless a few new diamonds
in the rough are suddenly discovered.

we expected to see. In spurts the

Election of the upper class officers
for the current year, to be held this
week and next, was to begin yesterday when nominations for sophomore class officers were received in
Latrobe Hall.
Sophomore class elections will be
held this Thursday when nominations
for the junior class officers will also
take place.
Next Monday the junior elections
and senior nominations will be held,
while senior officers will be elected
on the following Thursday.
Polls will be open on election days
from 12.30 to 1.30 p. m. A student
must have paid his class dues in order to be eligible to vote.

from the School of Engineering in

degree in mechanical engineering two
years later, has becothe an instructor
3.
at the Stevens Institute of Technolf
ogy, it was learned Saturday. He
served during 1933-34 on the University of Rochester faculty.

from the Hopkins, Yellott wrote his
thesis on an invention of his own by
Which steam flow in nozzles could be
examined optically.

June Week which featured Lombardo's Royal Canadians, member of the

- track "letter" man, and member of
the "Y" Board of Managers. He is
a member of Tau Beta Pi national
honorary engineering fraternity, Sigma Xi scientific fraternity, and Omicron Delta Kappa honorary activities fraternity.

Engineering School
Truthfully one of if not the most
versatile of the Hopkins football
players is Reuben Pasarew. Born in
this city August 12, 1914, Rube, as
he is known on the campus, attended primary school in this city before entering the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.
While at Poly Pasarew starred in
three sports: football, basketball and
lacrosse. In his senior year at Poly
Rube was captain of the lacrosse
team and received mention in the
All-Maryland selections.
Versatile Player
In the fall of 1932 he matriculated
in the School of Engineering at the
Johns Hopkins and promptly proceeded to "throw his hat into the
football ring." Pasarew made he
varsity in his first year at school,
playing most of the time on the line.
Last year, due to injuries to several
of the players and scarcity of varsity
material, Coach Van Orman alternated Rube in the backfield. But this
season finds Pasarew holding down
an end post for the Blue Jay eleven.

Ladder Tourney
For this reason Mr. Baer has decided to make the tournament not
an elimination but a ladder affair so
that students, more or less new or
inexperienced in this sport, will not
be eliminated from the contest immediately but will be given a chance to
learn the game.

In addition, Mr. Baer will himself
give personal instruction in handball
playing on informal occasions. Students will be permitted to play
matches or practice during free periods or after class hours.

Just A Few Of Our
Real Bright Spots
Most commendable was the work
of Captain Bill McClean. His excellent passing, kicking and field generalship led the Black and Blue thru
a hard fight. And while we're throwing orchids let's heave two at those
rugged guards, Otts Phillips and
Angy Giardini. Many a Lehigh line
thrust was broken up by their hard
charging and tackling.
On the offense the Blue Jays
showed a definite ability to pass their
way into scoring territory.

The Other Side
Of The Story
Our shortcoming lies in the rushing attack. Several off-tackle runs
were well executed but a majority of
the line bucks lacked everything that
should go with 'em.
Another very evident weakness was
the lack of reserve strength. On
several important occasions last Saturday, it was clear that the coaching
staff was at a loss when substitutes
were necessary. There doesn't seem
as though anything can be done
about this unless a few new diamonds
in the rough are suddenly discovered.

Lehigh, truthfully, wasn't the team
we expected to see. In spurts the
Brown and White showed real class
when on a few occasions almost every Hopkins player was taken out
for the Lehigh ball carrier, but that's
about all we can say for Coach Harmeson and his Notre Dame system.
So, because of and in spite of everything we've said, we're looking
forward to a real interesting battle
Saturday afternoon when the Jays
meet Washington College at Homewood. Don't forget, you freshmen,
be there to cheer your eleven on to a
victory!
